image.altText: Kadidiatou Diani barges past Alanna Kennedy

items.synopsis: The Matildas take on France with a spot in the FIFA Women's World Cup semifinal on the line in Brisbane. Follow all the updates in our live blog.

title.children: France challenge early as Sam Kerr starts on the bench for Matildas in Women's World Cup quarterfinal

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The corner comes in and finds its way to the feet of France's all-time leading goal-scorer Eugenie Le Sommer. She tries to hook in a volley, but only finds Maelle Lakrar, who was completely unmarked with Mackenzie Arnold utterly out of position, but the defender could only redirect the ball over the goal at a sharp angle. Another lucky escape for Australia.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 12' France misses an open goal!

children.content: The corner comes in and finds its way to the feet of France's all-time leading goal-scorer Eugenie Le Sommer. She tries to hook in a volley, but only finds Maelle Lakrar, who was completely unmarked with Mackenzie Arnold utterly out of position, but the defender could only redirect the ball over the goal at a sharp angle.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We are off and running. France tried their immediate attack from Sandie Toletti down the left and Emily van Egmond leapt in to shut it down. Easy money. But eventually they do find that ball down the left to Kdidiatou Diani and she puts in the cross, but it's headed clear by Alanna Kennedy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 1' France kicks off!

children.content: France tried their immediate attack from Sandie Toletti down the left and Emily van Egmond leapt in to shut it down.
But eventually they do find that ball down the left to Kdidiatou Diani and she puts in the cross, but it's headed clear by Alanna Kennedy.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Matildas captain Sam Kerr will come off the bench tonight, with coach Tony Gustavsson opting not to mess with the side that beat Denmark 2-0 in the round of 16. This comes after Gustavsson said yesterday she would absolutely start if they were confident she could get through 90 minutes plus extra time. I suppose even a sliver of doubt and you have to bring her off the bench, because if it goes to penalties, you really want her out there.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sam Kerr will not start tonight

children.content: Matildas captain Sam Kerr will come off the bench tonight, with coach Tony Gustavsson opting not to mess with the side that beat Denmark 2-0 in the round of 16.
Gustavsson said yesterday she would absolutely start
if they were confident she could get through 90 minutes plus extra time.
I suppose even a sliver of doubt and you have to bring her off the bench, because if it goes to penalties, you really want her out there.

props.alt: Sam Kerr walks down a hallway before Australia's Matildas play a Women's WOrld Cup quartefinal against France.

image.altText: Composite image of Shyanne-Lee Tatnell and mum with dove.

items.synopsis: The mother of murdered 14-year-old Shyanne-Lee Tatnell says she will "never be free from the grief" of losing her daughter, as mourners farewelled the teen who was described as "strong willed and rebellious".

title.children: 'My heart is beyond repair': Mum's sorrow for Shyanne-Lee Tatnell at funeral for Tasmanian teenager

image.altText: House in a rural setting with a sofa on porch

items.synopsis: A rural community stunned by the sudden loss of friends following suspected mushroom poisoning is grappling with its grief, while under the unfamiliar gaze of national and international media.

title.children: Grief grips small town in Victoria's south-east, while questions over deadly mushrooms remain

image.altText: A young blonde woman looks at us on the right, a blurry man sits behind her on the couch

items.synopsis: Emma and Adam Deane lost their son Jace at 24 weeks gestation. They're calling for hospital reform so others won't have to endure the same post-birth experience.

title.children: 'There are babies. You can hear crying': Why parents of stillborns are calling for bereavement rooms in hospitals

image.altText: Dozens of people of all ages line up outside a "For Lease" sign at a Sydney apartment building.

items.synopsis: There has been a lot of work going on behind the scenes in the lead-up to National Cabinet's housing crisis meeting this week – and it could potentially mark an important shift in the way governments think about housing, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: National Cabinet is turning its attention to Australia's housing crisis – and an important shift could be coming

image.altText: A glass with whisky sits on a coaster.

items.synopsis: Tasmania is slowly becoming a hub for whisky lovers, but it's not the first time the island state has seen a distilling boom.

title.children: Tasmania legally produced whisky before Scotland, so why did it stop for 150 years?

image.altText: Harris Andrews punches the ball away from the fingertips of two Adelaide players

items.synopsis: Brisbane are eyeing the top two and Adelaide the top eight as they meet for a critical clash at the Gabba. Follow our live AFL ScoreCentre.

title.children: AFL live: Lions tackle Crows in crucial match in the race the top eight

image.altText: Raider and Dragons

items.synopsis: The Raiders score a thrilling victory over the Dragons in the NRLW, as the Broncos and Cowboys also take home wins. Check out all the stats and latest news here.

title.children: Raiders claim NRLW golden-point thriller as Broncos and Cowboys also take home crucial points

image.altText: A close up of a red Sherrin brand Aussie Rules football, with blurred players in the background.

items.synopsis: A suburban football club official found to have run onto the field and attacked a young player during a match in Adelaide last weekend is handed a lifetime ban from official involvement in the sport.

title.children: Football official cops lifetime ban for attack on junior in under-13 match, SA league says

image.altText: Two images stitched together - one shows a Tesco bag of onions, grown in NZ, and the other shows a field in NZ

items.synopsis: Food prices in New Zealand are growing at the fastest rate in more than 30 years, but there are hopes a new grocery regulator will change things.

title.children: 'Why are we getting so badly ripped off?': How one bag of onions in the UK sparked outrage in NZ

image.altText: A court sketch depicts Donald Trump with his trademark coiffed blonde hair, raises one hand beside him

items.synopsis: A federal judge has cautioned the former US president his use of social media could expedite his election interference case as his legal woes mount.

title.children: 'Defence is supposed to happen in the courtroom': Donald Trump warned over social posts that threaten witnesses

image.altText: Man in suit walks to court as police officer escorts him.

items.synopsis: Former FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried shared private writings by former romantic partner Caroline Ellison with a New York Times reporter.

title.children: FTX's Sam Bankman-Fried headed for jail over alleged witness tampering

image.altText: Doc Neeson in full flight on stage with The Angels

items.synopsis: In 1983, an outback town told The Angels "No way, get f****d, f**k off". Forty years on, the band returns to where it all began.

title.children: 'Get f****d, f**k off!': Mystery uncovered behind Aussie chant as The Angels return to town where it all began

image.altText: A woman smiles while posing for a photo and holding a soccer ball on her shoulder.

items.synopsis: A life changing day for Matildas star Mackenzie Arnold has helped thrust the Deaf and hard of hearing community into the spotlight and provided a high profile role model for many.

title.children: How Matildas keeper Mackenzie Arnold's life-changing day is raising awareness of hearing loss

image.altText: Two women holding bowls of food standing against a wall with family photos on it, smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: Annabel Crabb reveals what happens behind the scenes filming Kitchen Cabinet and how cooking encourages politicians to open up.

title.children: When Annabel Crabb makes a dessert for Kitchen Cabinet there's an important factor she needs to consider

image.altText: A close up black and white shot of Ron S. Peno standing in front of a microphone with his arms raised

items.synopsis: Peno was the charismatic leader of the band, who were underground favourites in the 1980s and 90s and were nominated for three ARIA awards.

title.children: Lead singer of Died Pretty, Ron S Peno, dies in Melbourne after long illness

image.altText: A woman sitting besides a baby rcoker

items.synopsis: Stays in maternity hotels are becoming increasingly popular among Chinese women in Australia, with some new mothers paying up to $50,000 for 26 days.

title.children: Hiro had culture shock after giving birth in Australia – so she found a nanny to follow Chinese postpartum traditions

image.altText: A hand signs a signature with a pen at the end of a form or contract.

items.synopsis: Until now, millions of Australians have been saving in ways that you would expect – cutting back on discretionary items. But there's evidence that thriftiness has evolved to include what many might see as essential items, writes David Taylor.

title.children: From 'thrifty' to 'risky': The financial decisions more Australians are making to pay the mortgage

image.altText: A man holds a credit card while using a laptop

items.synopsis: Our banks remind us with no irony of the serious need to report fraud, but you shouldn't have to beg for someone to call you back when the most egregious of financial crimes is underway, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: The missing link in why people can lose so much to scams

image.altText: A composite image of an artist and an artwork.

items.synopsis: Zaachariaha Fielding started to take a serious interest in visual art when an Electric Fields tour of the US was cancelled because of the pandemic. Three years later, the singer-songwriter is now claiming painting prizes.

title.children: How 'gremlins' inspired Electric Fields singer to paint this prize-winning piece

image.altText: A young white woman with her two young kids. Both are smiling

items.synopsis: After a 10-month Senate inquiry handed down recommendations this week, families experiencing school refusal are hopeful their voices are being heard at last.

title.children: We still don't know the true scale of school refusal — but there are solutions we can look at right now

image.altText: George Harrison and Leo Sayer

items.synopsis: A music heart-throb of the 1970s and 80s, Leo Sayer finds a new audience by spreading hope through the wards of a Canberra hospital.

title.children: 'How much love?' At 75, Leo Sayer has swapped the life of pop stardom for secret singalongs in a Canberra hospital

image.altText: A man with white hair stands in a desert smiling

items.synopsis: Best known for his Mad Max franchise, Happy Feet and Babe, George Miller reflects on the thinkers who influenced him, most notably the American futurist Buckminster Fuller who taught the filmmaker to think of himself as a verb.

title.children: Mad Max director George Miller reveals his views on creativity, faith and living as a 'verb'

image.altText: A black and white image of Nas in the middle of a street looking back at the camera, two cars on either side

items.synopsis: This month marks the 50th birthday of hip hop. It's been a wild ride from the Bronx, NY — via the creation of Australia's own hip-hop identity — into the global pop culture force it is today.

title.children: Hip hop's wild ride from its beginnings in the Bronx to the suburbs of Australia

image.altText: A white, middle-aged woman with blonde hair rests her elbows on the back of a chair with her hands interlaced.

items.synopsis: The Miles Franklin-winning author takes on the patriarchy in her new book, Wifedom: Mrs Orwell's Invisible Life.

title.children: Anna Funder doesn't want to cancel George Orwell – she just wants to set the record straight

image.altText: David Schmeider and his son Laurie

items.synopsis: From coopers to luthiers, rare trades that are locked out of apprenticeship programs are leaving businesses without succession plans or extra staff to share the burden of work.

title.children: From coopers to luthiers, endangered trades and skills at risk of dying out in Australia

image.altText: Sam Cardone (second from right) with her family at the Colosseum in Rome.

items.synopsis: Sam Cardone hasn't had a problem taking her children on short trips during the school term. She says they're better off for the experience.

title.children: 'You learn a lot more': Is it OK to take your kids out of school to travel?

image.altText: Hands on a laptop keyboard. The screen is open to an Airbnb search.

items.synopsis: In dealing with both a digital platform and a private owner, your legal rights as an Airbnb renter can be unclear.

title.children: Can an Airbnb host ban you from having visitors? Six common questions about your rights as a guest

image.altText: A shorefront with burnt out cars and buildings.

items.synopsis: Cadaver dogs from California and Washington state are expected to arrive today to help with recovering human remains from the ruins, as more bodies are found.

title.children: Death toll climbs to 67 amid search for bodies on Maui, as residents say fire sirens didn't work

image.altText: A burning building next to palm trees blowing in strong wind

items.synopsis: As a fire scientist, I know the unfolding horror — which has killed more than 60 people — is just the beginning. It's a portent of what Australia and other countries will experience in a warmer world, writes David Bowman.

title.children: 'Australia is sleepwalking': The unfolding fire horror in Hawaii holds a message for Australia

image.altText: Portraits of Mark Zuckerberg and Elon Musk side by side

items.synopsis: The battle between rival billionaires Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg is heating up, with plans for an "ancient Rome"-themed showdown.

title.children: Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg cage fight to be held in 'epic location' in Italy
